title: Coca Cola bottlers agree three-way €28bn mega deal
text:
35.7499 -0.0701 
Coca-Cola Enterprises announces biggest European consumer deal for a century as it agrees to combine with Coca-Cola Iberian Partners and its German rival to create the world's biggest independent Coke bottler 
Coca-Cola Enterprises, the bottling group, has unveiled a three way merger with two of its counterparts in the biggest European consumer deal this century. 
The group has announced a deal to combine with Coca-Cola Iberian Partners and the German bottling business of the Coca-Cola Company. 
The new business, named Coca-Cola European Partners (CCEP), is expected to be worth around €28bn (£19.6bn). 
The CCEP deal is expected to achieve synergies of between $350m and $375m within three years of completing. 
The combination will mean that CCEP, which serves 300 million people in 13 territories spanning most of Western Europe, will have annual sales of around $12.6bn (£8bn) and earnings of $2.1bn. 
CCEP will be based in the UK as the three-way merger has been structured as an inversion deal , a type of structure that was thrust into the spotlight by Pfizer (NYSE: PFE - news ) 's pursuit of AstraZeneca (NYSE: AZN - news ) , in order to reduce its tax bill. 
It will be the largest ever inversion deal involving a consumer company, ahead of Burger King (EUREX: 18860462.EX - news ) 's $11.4bn takeover of doughnut chain Tim Hortons in 2014. 
CCEP will be listed on the Amsterdam Euronext, the New York Stock Exchange and the Madrid Stock Exchange. 
The new business will be the third largest consumer company on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange after conglomerate Unilever (NYSE: UL - news ) and brewer Heineken (Other OTC: HEINY - news ) . 
In November brewing giant SABMiller (Amsterdam: MI8.AS - news ) agreed a deal with bottling firm Coca-Cola sabco to form a new company to cover 40pc of all the fizzy drink sold in Africa. 
“The creation of Coca-Cola European Partners will build on each bottler’s capabilities to create more efficient operations in their respective markets across Western Europe,” said John Brock, chairman and chief executive officer of Coca-Cola Enterprises. 
Deutsche advised Coca-Cola Company, Lazard acted as lead financial adviser to CC and Rothschild advised Coca Cola Iberia.
